title: Analysis I
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. The course is intended to provide an introduction to linear structures and analysis covering fundamental concepts and techniques involving mathematical proofs for metric/ topological results in the one-dimensional and higher dimensional Euclidean spaces as well as in function spaces.

title: Linear Analysis
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. The course is intended to provide an introduction to linear structures and various concepts of limits/convergence in analysis especially in the context of Euclidean/Hilbert/Banach spaces as well as the Lebesgue integration spaces.
outcome: 1. To learn Hahn-Banach Theorem; 2. To learn Basic Banach Theory and Hilbert Theory; 3. Bounded Linear Operators.
syllabus: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. The course is intended to provide an introduction to linear structures and various concepts of limits/convergence in analysis especially in the context of Euclidean/Hilbert/Banach spaces as well as the Lebesgue integration spaces.
required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by the course teacher.

title: Analysis II
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. The prerequisite of this course is the mathematical contents of Analysis I. The course is intended to provide basic and fundamental knowledge of modern analysis involving limits and various notions of convergence in the context of metirc/normed vector/Hilbert spaces as well as the vector Lp spaces.

title: Algebra and Geometry
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. The course is an introduction to commutative algebra, in particular polynomial rings of one and several variables, their ideals and the associated varieties. The Hilbert basis theorem and Groebner bases algorithms are included.

title: Differential and Algebraic Methods in Geometry
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Degree Programme in Mathematics. The course is intended to provide an introduction to the geometry of curves and surfaces in 3 dimensional Euclidean space. The fundamental group and its application in the classification of closed surfaces will also be discussed.

title: Fourier Analysis
description: This course is an introduction to the theory and applications of Fourier analysis, intended for students of the MSc programme of Mathematics.

title: Topics in Number Theory
description: Divisibility of integers, theory of primes, fundamental theorem of Arithmetic, basic sieve methods, modular arithmetic, diophantine equations, cryptography, number theoretic functions, primitive roots, the quadratic reciprocity law, elliptic curves and other topics.
outcome: Students are able to: • Understand the basic idea and the proofs of some basic theorems in number theory  • Applications of number theory, e.g. cryptography • Acquire background knowledge in more advanced topics such as analytic number theory, algebraic number theory, etc.
syllabus: Divisibility of integers, theory of primes, Fundamental theorem of Arithmetic, basic sieve methods, modular arithmetic, diophantine equations, cryptography, number theoretic functions, primitive roots, the quadratic reciprocity law, elliptic curves and other topics.
required_readings: Please refer to the teaching materials
recommended_readings: • Elementary Number Theory by D.M. Burton, Mcgraw-Hill, 7th ed. • The Theory of Numbers, by I. Niven, H.S. Zuckerman, H.L. Montgomery, John Wiley & Sons Inc, 5th ed.

title: Topics in Geometry
description: This course is intended to provide a brief, but solid, modern introduction to various basic geometries using analytic methods.

title: Topics in Differential Equations
description: This course aims to provide with students a short and yet concise introduction to ordinary differential equations (O.D.E.). We will cover the conventional topics such as classifications of O.D.E., first order equations, linear second and higher order equations. If time permits, we may indicate heuristically how existence and uniqueness theorems are to be proved. Other optional topics may include: power series method, Frobenius’ series method, two-point boundary value problems, Sturm-Liouville problems, non-linear systems.

title: Probability Theory
description: This is a course designed for the M.Sc. program. It aims to provide a basic but rigorous (both in theory and in applications) course in elementary probability theory.

title: Discrete Mathematics
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. The course is an introduction to discrete mathematics; topics will be chosen from: set theory, number theory, algebraic structures, recurrence relations and generating functions, rudiments of analysis of algorithms, finite geometries, (combinatorial) design theory, coding theory, graph theory, and various methods in combinatorics.

title: Complex Analysis and Its Applications
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. The course is intended to provide an introduction to the analysis and applications of analytic functions on the complex plane. Emphasis will be placed on the understanding and appreciation of the theory as well as its wide range of usage. It includes the study of integrals, residues, series expansion, and conformality of analytic functions; transforms and their use in differential equations.
outcome: 1. To learn the theory of single variable complex functions. 2. To study and appreciate classical results such as Cauchy integral theorem, residue theorem, fundamental theorem of algebra and Picard’s Theorem. 3. To prepare further study on subjects such as harmonic analysis and complex geometry.
syllabus: The course is intended to provide an introduction to the analysis and applications of analytic functions on the complex plane. Emphasis will be placed on the understanding and appreciation of the theory as well as its wide range of usage. It includes the study of integrals, residues, series expansion, and conformality of analytic functions; transforms and their use in differential equations.
required_readings: Complex variables and applications (9th edition by Brown and Churchill)
recommended_readings: Complex Analysis (Elias Stein) Complex Analysis: an introduction to the theory of analytic (Lars Ahlfors)

title: Mathematics for Logistics
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. The course provides the basic mathematical tools for logistics. Topics include: linear and nonlinear programming, resource allocation problem, shortest route problem, inventory and production problem, cargo loading problem, equipment replacement problem, reliability problem, max flow problem, decision tree analysis, production theory, maintenance and reliability theory.
outcome: Students are able to: • gain an understanding of the general concepts of the basic theory and algorithms behind linear and integer linear programming.  • learn a method of analyzing a problem by constructing, solving and interpreting the solution(s) of a linear optimization problem.
syllabus: This course provides the basic mathematical tools for logistics. Topics may include linear and nonlinear programming, resource allocation problem, shortest route problem, inventory and production problems, cargo loading problems, equipment replacement problems, reliability problems, max flow problems, decision tree analysis, production theory, maintenance, and reliability theory.
required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by the course teacher.
recommended_readings: Operations Research: An Introduction by H.F. Taha Introduction to Operations Research by F.S. Hillier and G.J. Lieberman Linear and Nonlinear Programming by D.G. Luenberger and Y.Y. Ye Introduction to Linear Optimization by D. Bertsimas and J.N. Tsitsiklis

title: Optimization and Modeling
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Degree Programme in Mathematics. The course provides an introduction to theory and numerical methods for optimization and modeling.

title: Financial Mathematics
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. The course is an introductory course on Financial Mathematics. Topics include probability, hedging, arbitrage, vanilla options, binomial models, the Black-Scholes formula, exotic options, Monte Carlo methods and binomial methods.
outcome: 1. To provide students with a good understanding of financial mathematics, as well as the methods and techniques used in the area to model and analyse financial data. 2. To provide experience of practical applications of mathematics, including mathematical modelling, probability theories and differential equations, in financial modelling. 3. To develop students' ability to critically analyse various financial models for different practical applications.
syllabus: The course is an introductory course on Financial Mathematics. Topics include probability, hedging, arbitrage, vanilla options, binomial models, the Black-Scholes formula, exotic options, Monte Carlo methods and binomial methods.
required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by the course teacher.
recommended_readings: Options, Futures, and Other Derivatives, by Hull, J. Financial Mathematics, Derivatives and Structured Products, by Chan, R., Guo, Y., Lee, S.T., and Li, X.

title: Calculus of Variations
description: Extremal problems from mechanics and geometry; First variations and Euler-Lagrange Equations; Constrained variational problems, Lagrange mulitipliers; Second variations and Jacobi necessary condition for weak extrema; and topics chosen from: Hamiltonian formation, Noether theorem on conservation laws, Weierstrass E-function and strong extrema.

title: Introduction to Inverse Problems
requirements: For students in MSc Programme in Mathematics
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Degree Programme in Mathematics. The course is intended to provide an introduction to inverse problems and their computational techniques.

title: Financial Analytics
requirements: For students in MSc Programme in Mathematics
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. This course focuses on the study of multiple and granular views of the real world’s financial data and use it to gain insight and take action through the lens of statistical/mathematical/computational modelling together with computing software, e.g., MATLAB, Python and/or R. The aim of this course is to provide students with practical skills relating to financial modelling and the quantitative analysis of financial data and issues. Students will become familiar with essential topics/case-studies selected from, but not limited to, including, Mathematical Finance, Portfolio and Risk Management, Optimization Methods in Finance, Financial Forecasting, Numerical and Computational Financial Methods and Financial Management.
outcome: On completion of this course, students will be able to: • Analyze, evaluate, interpret, organize and synthesize information in a practical and quantitative manner. • Undertake in-depth detailed numerical computation and analysis of financial data and information.  • Undertake an independent analysis of a given data set using MATLAB, Python, and/or R. • Apply sophisticated financial modelling techniques to critically examine financial statements and opportunities. • Critically evaluate the findings resulting from the application of financial modelling techniques.
syllabus: A broad base of knowledge with in-depth analysis and skills development will be covered, including, Financial Statistics, Financial Securities, Time Series Analysis, The Sharpe Ratio, Markowitz Mean-Variance Optimization, Network Analysis, Cluster Analysis, Trading Strategies and Option Pricing Models and so on.
required_readings: The course will mainly follow the lecture notes.
recommended_readings: • Mark J Bennett,‎ Dirk L Hugen (2016) Financial Analytics with R: Building a Laptop Laboratory for Data Science, Cambridge University Press, 1st Edition, 2016. • Edward E Williams (2017) Quantitative Financial Analytics: The Path to Investment Profits, World Scientific Publishing Company, 1st Edition, 2017.

title: Computational Mathematics
requirements: For students in MSc Programme in Mathematics
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. The course is intended to provide an introduction to computational mathematics and their applications.
outcome: Students are able to - understand the basics in computational mathematics, - apply various mathematical methods to solve practical applications, - solve large scale problems by iterative techniques.
syllabus: Topics include ill-posed problems, least-squares problems, singular value decompositions, regularization techniques, discrepancy principle, classical iterative techniques, projection methods, Arnoldi methods, Krylov subspace methods, conjugate gradient methods, GMRES methods, and applications to image processing, computerized tomography and PDE parameter identification problems.
recommended_readings: • Charles Groetsch, Inverse Problems in the Mathematical Sciences • Andreas Kirsch, An Introduction to the Mathematical Theory of Inverse Problems • Jennifier Muller and Samuli Slitanen, Linear and Nonlinear Inverse Problems with Practical Applications • Lloyd N. Trefethen and David Bau III, Numerical Linear Algebra • Yousef Saad, Iterative Methods for Sparse Linear Systems

locations: Chung Chi College Lib CK TSE

title: Econometric Principles and Data Analysis
requirements: For students in MSc Programme in Mathematics
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. This course is focused on the importation of mathematical and statistical concepts, theories, methods and limitations into economic and data science and provides an overview of econometric methods and data analysis that allows analysts to better understand their economic/business landscape and to improve their ability to make sound economic/business forecasts. Through hands-on exercises based on the information flow of sample data together with available computing software, e.g., MATLAB, Python and/or R programming languages, participants gain knowledge of the practical elements of applied econometric analysis. The overall aim is to sharpen the quantitative, numerical, statistical and analytical skills of participants in dealing with real world examples and issues related to business and economic models.
outcome: On completion of this course, students will be able to: • Summarize and describe data through mathematical and statistical techniques and work with data and communicate data-driven findings effectively. • Develop and use econometric models. • Have an improved ability to make sound forecasts. • Use the computing software, e.g., MATLAB, Python and/or R programming languages to perform self-directed empirical analyses.  • Have sharper the quantitative, statistical, numerical and analytical skills.  • Be more effective at translating technical information for key decision-makers.
syllabus: A broad base of knowledge with in-depth analysis and skills development will be covered, including, Data Considerations and Managements, Estimation, Regression and Econometrics, Prediction, Experimental Design, Simulation Based Methods (e.g., Bootstrap, Monte Carlo, Indirect Inference), Machine Learning, Data Visualization and so on.
required_readings: The course will mainly follow the lecture notes.
recommended_readings: • S. Washington, M. Karlaftis, and F. Mannering (2011) Statistical and econometric methods for transportation data analysis, 2nd Edition, Chapman & Hall/CRC, Boca Raton, FL. • W. Greene (2010). Econometric Analysis, 7th Edition, Pearson. • J. M. Wooldridge (2012). Introductory Econometrics: A Modern Approach, 5th Edition, Cengage Publications. • F. Heiss (2016). Using R for introductory econometrics, 1st Edition Dusseldorf.

title: Probability and Stochastic Analysis
requirements: For students in MSc Programme in Mathematics
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. This course focusses on the rigorous foundation in probability and Markov chains theory with applications in different areas. No prior knowledge of measure theory is assumed.
outcome: Upon completion the course, students will be able to  - Understand the basic rigorous theory of probability, for example, expectation, conditional expectation, Central Limit Theorem.  - Apply Markov chain theory to economics, queues and the other topics.
syllabus: Topics include:  1. Axioms of probability, conditional probability, random variables and Limit Theorems.  2. Poisson processes, Markov chains, Birth processes and basic theory of martingales.
recommended_readings: - S. Ross, A first course in probability, 9th edition, Pearson, (2014). - J.R. Norris, Markov Chains, Cambridge University Press, (1998).

title: Coding Theory
requirements: For students in MSc Programme in Mathematics
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. This course aims to introduce a subject of basic theory and practical relevance. Students are expected to have basic knowledge in algebra.

title: Game Theory
requirements: For students in MSc Programme in Mathematics
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. This course aims to introduce the principles and techniques of game theory. Students are expected to have knowledge in linear algebra.

title: Social and Economic Networks: Theory, Modelling and Computations
requirements: For students in MSc Programme in Mathematics
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics. This course provides an overview of quantitative methods appropriate for the data analysis of social and economic networks. Many social and economic activities are embedded in networks because datasets with graph theoretic structure are increasingly available to practical users. Two of the main goals are to study • how to describe, summarize and visually present network data together with computing software, e.g., MATLAB, Python and/or R and • formal econometric models of network formation that admit heterogeneity, strategic behavior, and/or dynamics. Theoretical/statistical/mathematical/computational models and their applications with respect to social and network data from development and labor economics are studied. Essential topics/case-studies are selected from, but not limited to, network formation, peer effects and the social multiplier, social capital and trust, information aggregation in networks, social learning, trading in networks, technology diffusion, job search, and other related topics.
outcome: On completion of this course, students will be able to: • Master knowledge and understanding of the current research on the economics of social networks. • Read research papers in this field. • Present and critically discuss research papers in this field. • Have sufficient understanding of open issues to formulate a new research question in this field. • Undertake an independent analysis of a given data set using MATLAB, Python, and/or R.
syllabus: A broad base of knowledge with in-depth analysis and skills development will be covered, including Theoretical and Empirical Background, Peer Effects, Opinion Formation Through Social Learning, Social Capital and Trust, Labor Markets, Favoritism and Political Connections, Firm Networks, Financial Networks, Network Formation: evidence and random graph models, Network Games, and Trading in Networks.
required_readings: The course will mainly follow the lecture notes.
recommended_readings: • M. O. Jackson (2008). Social and Economic Networks, 1st Edition, Princeton University Press. • G. Knieps (2015). Network Economics: Principles – Strategies – Competition Policy, 1st Edition, Springer. • E. D. Kolaczyk, G. Csardi (2014). Statistical Analysis of Network Data with R, 1st Edition, Springer.

title: Graph Theory and Networks
requirements: For students in MSc Programme in Mathematics
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Degree programme. This course covers some fundamental concepts and principles of graph theory and networks. Transferring some big-data problems to graph models will be introduced. In order to solve such problems, some algorithms of graphs and networks are also discussed. No prior knowledge is assumed.

title: Mathematical Image Processing
requirements: For students in MSc Programme in Mathematics
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Degree programme. This course gives an introduction on mathematical models and techniques for various image processing tasks. A wide array of topics will be covered, including image restoration (denoising, deblurring), image decomposition, image segmentation, image registration, feature detection, multi-scale image analysis, morphology and so on. Students will become familiar with essential mathematical techniques for imaging tasks, such as image processing in the spatial domain (using gradient, Laplacian, convolution) and frequency domain (using Fourier / wavelet transform). Variational models and PDE-based techniques will be discussed. Deep-learning based techniques will also be explored. Students are expected to have basic knowledge in calculus, linear algebra and MATLAB language. Some background in numerical analysis, Fourier analysis and partial differential equations will be helpful, although the necessary concepts will be discussed as they are used.
outcome: On completion of this course, students will be able to: • Understand in-depth the various topics in image processing and the technical difficulties in solving them • Learn how to use various mathematical models to solve different imaging problems  • Systematically evaluate the performance of different models to solve various imaging problems • Understand the importance of mathematical imaging for real-world problems
syllabus: Cover various topics related to mathematical image processing, including: Basic concepts in digital image processing, Image decomposition and image compression, Image enhancement in the frequency domain, Image enhancement in the spatial domain, Image segmentation, deep learning based techniques for imaging.
required_readings: The course will mainly follow the lecture notes.

title: Mathematical Theories of Machine Learning
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Degree Programme in Mathematics. The aim of this course is to introduce the mathematical foundations of and optimization techniques used in machine learning. Both theoretical and numerical approaches for tackling mathematical problems arising from machine learning will be introduced. Learning will be enhanced through software implementation of the computational methods. Topics will be selected from, but not limited to, predictive modeling, classification, neural networks, support vector machines and other related topics. This course assumes no prior experience with programming.

title: Mathematical Principles of Artificial Intelligence
description: This course offers a mathematically introductory view of the theoretical foundation and practical approach/technique to artificial intelligence (AI) and serves as a basis for more in depth treatment of specific theories for building AI by means of computing software, e.g., MATLAB, Python and/or R. The aim of this course is to illustrate both the potential and current limitations of different AI techniques with examples from a variety of applications. Students will become familiar with computational models of intelligence behavior as well as essential topics/case-studies selected from, but not limited to, including, Searching Algorithm, Data Mining, Information Retrieval, Computational Neuroscience, Social Intelligence in Computing, and Semantic Analysis.
outcome: On completion of this course, students will be able to: • Identify the historical basis for the latest developments, achievements and designs of AI techniques • Have knowledge about how to apply AI methods to different types of applications  • Understand the strengths and weaknesses of different AI approaches in terms of human decision-making and learning • Undertake in-depth detailed numerical computation and algorithms of AI problems  • Undertake an independent analysis of a given AI problem using MATLAB, Python, and/or R. • Be able to search for literature outlining state-of-the-art within a specific research area • Be able to critically assess scientific research papers and have experience in presenting scientific work for others • Be able to design and conduct numerical experiments using AI methods, with emphasis on evaluation and testing
syllabus: A broad base of knowledge with in-depth analysis and skills development will be covered, with topics, including, but not limited to, Introduction to AI, Problem Solving through Search, Knowledge Representation and Inference, Representing and Reasoning with Uncertain Knowledge, Decision Making, Learning and Knowledge Acquisition, Natural Language Processing, Financial Services and so on.
required_readings: The course will mainly follow the lecture notes.
recommended_readings: - Russell, S., & Norvig, P. Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach, Prentice-Hall, 2010. - Pearl, J. Causality: Models, Reasoning, and Inference. New York: Cambridge University Press, 2000 - Luce, D., & Raiffa, H. Games and Decisions: Introduction and Critical Survey. Dover, 2012. - Duda, R., Hart, P., & Stork, D. Pattern Classification. New York: Wiley, 2001. - Tan, P-N., Steinbach, M., & Kumar, V. Introduction to Data Mining. New York: Addison-Wesley, 2004. - Yang, Q. Intelligent Planning: A Decomposition and Abstraction Based Approach. Berlin: Springer, 1998. - Grossman, D. A. & Frieder, O. Information Retrieval: Algorithms and Heuristics. Berlin: Springer, 2004. - Haykin, S. O. Neural Networks and Learning Machines, Pearson, 2009. - Goodfellow, I., Bengio, Y., & Courville, A. Deep Learning, MIT Press, 2016.

title: Guided Studies I
description: A project in pure or applied mathematics, either in research or in reviewing the literature of an advanced topic. Each section may be taken by an individual student or a team of two students. Topics selected should be beyond the content of MMAT5000. Prerequisite: permission of the instructor.

title: Guided Studies II
description: This course is a continuation of MMAT5410. A project in pure or applied mathematics, either in research or in reviewing the literature of an advanced topic. Each section may be taken by an individual student or a team of two students. Topics selected should be beyond the content of MMAT5000. Prerequisite: permission of the instructor.

title: Graduate Seminar I
description: Series of projects in pure or applied mathematics focusing on a central theme. Topics selected should be beyond the content of MMAT5000. Prerequisite: permission of the instructor.

title: Graduate Seminar II
description: This course is a continuation of MMAT5430. Series of projects in pure or applied mathematics focusing on a central theme. Topics selected should be beyond the content of MMAT5000. Prerequisite: permission of the instructor.

title: Foundation of Advanced Mathematics
requirements: For students in MSc Mathematics Education
description: The course is intended to build a solid foundation for the students on the essential topics and the rigorous reasoning of mathematics. It includes the discussion of logic, sets and functions, cardinality and countability, basic number theory, real number and limits. (Not for undergraduate students, students in the MSc. Programme in Mathematics, and students who have taken MAT/MATH5011, 5012, 5031, 5032, 5051, 570S, 6xxx and 7xxx.)
outcome: Students are able to: • Read and write mathematical statements. • Prove elementary mathematical results. • Understand and apply elementary results in advanced mathematics. • Appreciate the usefulness of rigorous reasoning in mathematics.
syllabus: Topics may be chosen amongst:  • Mathematical statements and predicates; • Basic methods of proofs; • Basic number theory; • Basic results in set operations; • Logic; • Functions; • Infinite sets; • The notion of limits; • Relations and the number systems.
recommended_readings: • I. Stewart, D. Tall, The Foundation of Mathematics (Second Edition) • K. G. Binmore, Foundations of Analysis: a straightforward introduction (Book 1 Logic, Sets and Numbers) • W. Barnier, N. Feldman, Introduction to Advanced Mathematics (Second Edition); • G. Chartrand, A. D. Polimeni, P. Zhang, Mathematical Proofs: A Transition to Advanced Mathematics

title: Differential Equation and Linear Algebra
requirements:
For students in MSc Programme in Math Education.
Undergraduate students, students in the MSc. Programme in Mathematics, and students who have taken MAT/MATH5011, 5012, 5031, 5032, 5051, 570S, 6xxx and 7xxx are not allowed to take the course.
description: The course is intended to provide an amalgamated treatment of Differential Equations and Linear Algebra. Emphasis will be placed on algebraic intuition and geometric visualization, together with illustrations of applications. (Not for undergraduate students, students in the MSc. Programme in Mathematics, and students who have taken MAT/MATH5011, 5012, 5031, 5032, 5051, 570S, 6xxx and 7xxx.)

title: Finite Mathematics and Mathematical Programming
requirements: For students in MSc Mathematics Education
description: The course is intended to discuss mathematical methods frequently applied in managerial, business and social studies. It starts with a review of Linear Equations, then the main topics are selected from Linear Programming and Simplex Method, Counting and Probability, Game Theory, Basic Finance Mathematics, Mathematical Modelling. (Not for undergraduate students, students in the MSc. Programme in Mathematics, and students who have taken MAT/MATH5011, 5012, 5031, 5032, 5051, 570S, 6xxx and 7xxx.)

title: Advanced Geometry
requirements: For students in MSc Mathematics Education
description: This course mainly introduces students to the fundamental concepts of analytic geometry and vector geometry. It covers topics such as plane analytic geometry, Cartesian and Polar coordinates, transformation of coordinates, pairs of straight lines, circles, conic sections, direction cosines, direction ratios, planes, parametric equations, and vectors. Additional topics such as Euclidean Geometry, Non-Euclidean Geometry, Transformational Geometry, Projective Geometry, Geometric Symmetries, or Finite Geometry may be included. (Not for undergraduate students, students in the MSc. Programme in Mathematics, and students who have taken MAT/MATH5011, 5012, 5031, 5032, 5051, 570S, 6xxx and 7xxx.)
outcome: Upon completing this course, students will be able to:1.     Demonstrate a comprehensive understanding of the fundamental concepts in analytic geometry and vector geometry2.     Apply knowledge of analytic geometry and vector geometry to solve mathematical problems3.     Appreciate and understand how to develop analytic geometry based on Euclidean axioms4.     Utilize geometry principles and techniques to model and solve real-world problems5.     Communicate mathematical ideas and solutions effectively, both orally and in written form, using appropriate mathematical language and notation6.     Get a glimpse of other geometries, such as hyperbolic geometry, elliptic geometry, absolute geometry, projective geometry, geometric symmetries, or finite geometry.完成本課程後，學生將能夠：1.     全面理解解析幾何和向量幾何的基本概念。2.     應用解析幾何和向量幾何的知識解決數學問題。3.     欣賞並理解如何基於歐幾里德公理發展解析幾何。4.     運用幾何原理和技巧對現實世界問題進行建模和解決。5.     以口頭和書面形式有效地傳達數學思想和解決方案，使用適當的數學語言和符號。6.     簡要了解其他幾何學領域，例如雙曲幾何，橢圓幾何，射影幾何，幾何對稱性或有限幾何。
syllabus: The main focus of this course is to explore two topics: analytic geometry and vector geometry. Based on these, we will discuss selected topics in Euclidean geometry, non-Euclidean geometries, projective geometry, etc. in an introductory way.本課程主要探索解析幾何和向量幾何。此外，還可能包括歐式幾何、非歐幾何、變換幾何、射影幾何、幾何對稱或有限幾何。
required_readings: Chosen note or typed notes by the instructor.
recommended_readings: Stillwell, John: The Four Pillars of Geometry.

title: Introduction to Combinatorics
requirements: For students in the MSc Programme in Mathematics Education only
description: This course is an introduction of combinatorics, which includes basic counting techniques, pigeonhole principle, generating function. Further topics will be chosen from probability theory, graph theory, partition theory, geometric combinatorics, game theory and design theory.
outcome: Students are able to: • understand the fundamental concepts of combinatorics • use techniques acquired in this course to solve application problems • encompass an appreciation of the interplay between theory and practice
syllabus: Basic counting techniques, Permutation and Combination, Binomial theorem, Pigeonhole principle, Inclusion-exclusion principle, Recurrence relations, Generating functionAdditional topics may include:Probability theory, Graph theory, Planar graph, Eulerian Path, Partition theory, Geometric combinatorics, Game theory, Design theory基本計數技巧、排列及組合、二項式定理、鴿巢原理、排容原理、遞迴關係、生成函數 其他課題可能包括:概率論、圖論、平面圖、歐拉路徑、分拆理論、幾何組合學、對策論、設計理論
required_readings: Please refer to the course outline provided by the course teacher.
recommended_readings: • John M. Harris, Jeffry L. Hirst, Michael J. Mossinghoff (2000), Combinatorics and Graph Theory, Springer Science & Business Media. • George E. Martin (2001), Counting: The Art of Enumerative Combinatorics, Springer Science & Business Media.

title: Mathematics Enhancement for Teachers
requirements: For students in the MSc Programme in Mathematics Education only
description: This course is designed for the M.Sc. Programme in Mathematics Education. This course aims to provide a solid mathematical background for teaching professionals.
